characters: EXT. KNOLL ABOVE BRADLEY'S PLACE, (HOMESTEADER LAND)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. Quiet. The CAMERA MOVES through the gloom of th small, dirty, wooden hut, past a broken table, over a wel worn saddle lying on the floor. Now, a pair of boots stan empty by the rotting remains of a rough-hewn bunk, up to holstered gun hung on the corner of the bed. The still sh of a man, a bedroll his only protection from the splinter planks. This is EMMETT, fast asleep. The door of the shack bursts inward as a Gunman crashes i For a moment he is silhouetted against the blinding morni light, his two six-guns blasting even before the door has bounced shut behind him, returning the hut to darkness. Emmett's holster, the gun gone. The gun is here in Emmett's hand, erupting now with three quick explosions. The intruder flies against the far wall the hut and lands on the floor dead. From outside, two bu pierce the plank wall behind Emmett, light streaming thro in .45 calibre shafts. Emmett is out of the bunk and on the floor. He fires once over the bunk. In the moment of quiet that follows, we he running FOOTSTEPS outside the hut. Emmett follows their  progress with the point of his gun, but holds his fire.  Suddenly a shotgun blasts a large hole in the roof of the shack, and the table disintegrates in a new column of lig Emmett glances upward, but quickly returns his attention the side walls, trying to follow that gunman. Now more fi comes from there and more footsteps. Another shotgun blas showers Emmett with debris, but he ignores it, concentrat on the walls. WHAT HE SEES. The Man Outside moves quickly past a crack the wall, momentarily revealing his spot by blocking the  light. Emmett fires once ahead of him, stopping his progr and forcing him back to the crack. Emmett fires his last  shot there, and the man outside goes down hard. The shotgun rips another jagged hole in the ceiling and b a crater in the dirt by Emmett's foot. The shape of a man flashes across the new hole. Emmett looks across the room the top bunk, where the barrel of his Winchester protrude few inches from the bare planks. Emmett throws his empty gun noisily into the far corner of the hut. Instantly the man on the roof blasts away in that direction. Emmett dives for the bunk. With the tips of his fingers, pulls hard on the muzzle. The Winchester flips full circl into the air as the bunk behind it is shredded from above With an odd kind of inevitability, as though seeking its  rightful place, the Winchester arcs into a shaft of light where it is met by Emmett's steady, waiting hands. Before has even settled, he has cocked and fired twice through a hole in the roof. Emmett stops and lowers the carbine. Th Man on the Roof falls spread-eagled through the weakened  ceiling. Debris and sunlight shower his lifeless form. Emmett listens, moves silently to the door, and opens it  carefully. WE FOLLOW him outside, out into the bright  sunlight, into the awesome promise of the American West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett moves warily around the isolated shack. There are more attackers. He looks off into the distance. Two rider horses, galloping away, are the only moving things in the empty landscape. A third saddled horse, a pinto, stands  nervously near Emmett's horse, which is tied to a stake. Emmett walks to the body of the Man Outside and looks dow at him. He doesn't know him. He moves to the pinto and ca it. He examines the distinctive brand on its flank, a cir with two wavy lines beneath it. Emmett is clearly mystifi He rests his arms on the saddle and stares after the  retreating horses. THE MAIN TITLE BEGINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett travels, the saddled pinto in tow. He moves from h mountain terrain down-country, through meadow and canyon. makes night camp near a rushing stream. The land flattens he approaches the desert. The sun beats at him as he dism at the edge of a white-hot plain. He takes a short pull f his canteen and squints off across the flat, empty space. All he can see ahead is blinding sand and blue sky. THE MAIN TITLE ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett is now surrounded by the white blankness, moving s under the broiling sun. He stops his walking horses and squints out into the dist seeing something. We see it too, but just barely: a dista horizontal smudge on the glaring sand. Emmett reaches the smudge. It is a man, barefoot and dres only in longjohns, his head propped on a rock, eyes close The man's skin is burned red and beginning to blister, hi lips parched. Yet there is a curious ease to his repose. he has lain down here to die, he has done it in peace. Th is PADEN. Emmett lifts Paden's head and puts the canteen to his lip Paden's eyes struggle to open in the glare. He takes a fe sips of the water. His lips crack with a slight smile at taste. He looks up at Emmett, takes another sip, and trie to speak. Emmett must lean down to hear his raspy whisper he tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The terrain here is more hospitable. Paden, wrapped snugl in a blanket, lies with his head against the saddle from pinto. Emmett is preparing his bedroll across the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of the horses ran off, but that  pinto you're riding hung around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got no idea what they were after?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett shakes his head "no".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Offend anybody lately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for five years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson City?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Leavenworth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been in there. They just  jumped you out of the blue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to get up anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Me, I'm riding along, minding my own  business. Four cowboys come by and  we decide to ride together for a  while, friendly as can be. I always  figure you might as well approach  life like everybody's your friend or  nobody is... don't make much  difference. We get out in the middle  of that frying pan and suddenly  everybody's pointing their gun but  me. I guess they admired my horse.  She's a great one, a sweet little  bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like that's not all they  admired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. The whole rig. I don't care  much about the rest, but I surely  will miss that bay. Least they didn't  kill me. That was right considerate,  I thought. They were laughing when  they left me. Thought it was real  funny. I walked for a little while  but there was no use, so I gave it  up. Figured it was just bad luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett comes over and fills Paden's coffee cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like those boys are headed  south, so they weren't the same ones  that jumped me. Which way you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the pinto going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta stop by Turley and meet a  guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Turley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: South of here, past Chimayo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll go along as far as Chimayo.  Get me some clothes. Maybe a bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe a bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett settles down at his saddle and pulls a blanket ove himself. Paden glances at the rifle in its scabbard on th pinto's saddle by his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this loaded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett nods and closes his eyes. Paden smiles at the impl trust and settles down himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett and Paden, who is still clad only in longjohns, ri toward the low, adobe settlement of Chimayo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett and Paden enter the town past a cluster of teepees Three Cavalry troopers ride past them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little settlement is the center of civilization for m around. The U. S. Cavalry maintains an outpost here, and  there are many soldiers on the street. Emmett and Paden p up to the general store. Paden dismounts and hands his re to Emmett. Passersby look with curiosity at the undressed Paden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get these horses tended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden nods and looks doubtfully at the store. He scratche himself. Emmett produces some money and flips Paden a coi Paden nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm good for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett rides up the street, leading the pinto. Paden star toward the store and nearly collides with a shocked woman who covers the eyes of the little girl with her and cross the street. Paden gives an apologetic tip to his non-exis hat as he watches them go. Before he can turn back to the store, his eye is caught by something up the street. He r big. WHAT HE SEES. His horse, a good-looking bay. And, dawdlin his way out of a saloon, a disreputable-looking Cowboy. Paden's hand slaps his side, where his gun should be. He  grimaces and looks around desperately, then hurries into store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lone CLERK is showing a woman customer a bolt of clot at the back of the store. Paden hurries in and makes a be line to the display case holding handguns and ammo. He sp something he likes and taps the glass impatiently. The Cl reacts with distaste to Paden's appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be with you in a moment, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden looks out the front window, up the street. The Cowb is untying the bay's reins. Paden, more agitated now, glances back at the Clerk, then moves around and opens the back of the display case. He  extracts a shiny, new Colt .45. The Clerk reacts with ala and moves toward Paden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute there, fella. When I'm  done with this lady --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops his coin on the case top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at coin) That one's twenty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden is frustrated. He leans to peer out the window agai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much to borrow it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These guns are for sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates his coin) What can I get for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk gives up on putting him off and comes around th display case, disgruntled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy mounts the bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden holds a broken-down memory of a gun as though it we a cow chip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resigned) What's it take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk holds up a box of shells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is extra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden snatches it from his grasp and heads out of the sto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden hurries out into the middle of the street. Several  passersby stop to look at him. A teenage girl lets out a  delighted shriek. IN FRONT OF THE SALOON. The Cowboy has turned the bay int the middle of the street and now looks to see what all th fuss is about. When he makes out Paden standing alone, hi expression changes. Paden is having trouble extracting a shell from the ammo  box. He glances up the street at the Cowboy and sees that has been spotted. He shakes one shell loose and drops the box, trying to insert the bullet in the gun. The Cowboy pulls his six-gun, leans forward, and spurs th bay hard toward Paden. He raises his gun and fires at Pad There is general alarm in the street as the bystanders di for cover. Paden gets the shell loaded as the Cowboy bears down on h firing. The bullets kick up the dust in front and back of Paden, who now raises his pistol slowly. A bullet tears  through the floppy material at his crotch. The Cowboy is  almost upon him when Paden fires. The Cowboy is knocked o the horse and hits the street dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big, tough Cavalry SERGEANT has been summoned by a TROO and now walks briskly toward -- A small crowd gathered around Paden, who is affectionatel stroking his reacquired horse. Two troopers flank him  suspiciously. The Sergeant glances at the body of the Cow then pushes through the crowd and confronts Paden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Paden) This is the man, Sergeant. He claims  the animal was stolen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know this is your horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bay nuzzles Paden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you see this horse loves me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a gal do that to me, but that  didn't make her my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what, on the underside  of this saddle I got my name  scratched. Take a look and you'll  see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, and what would your name  be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sergeant and Paden both look to see COBB come through the crowd; he is an imposing man in a duster. Paden's rea is deep and mixed, a whole chapter in his life coming bac at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Hello, Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Paden. How ya doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know this man, Cobb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I surely do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to troopers) Let's see that saddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the troopers uncinches the saddle and flops it ups down in the dust. "Paden" is scratched on the underside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (satisfied) All right, move along, folks. Get  these children out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd begins to break up. Paden and Cobb are left fac one another. Cobb takes in Paden's longjohns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you're prospering without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden's look pierces Cobb, but he bends to pick up his sa and when he straightens, there is a smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb and Paden come out of the general store and start do the sidewalk. Paden is a little unsteady in a pair of che boots. A small pile of clothing is in his arms. On his he is a bad-looking new hat. He catches his reflection in a  window and tries to give the hat a rakish tilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appreciate the loan. I'm good for  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk about that. (a beat) I'm looking for some men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've given that up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So have I. I've got a legitimate job  now. I can use a guy like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtful) You've got a legitimate job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. You wouldn't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb stops and faces Paden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is mighty sweet, Paden. I think  I finally found my place in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm real happy for you, Cobb.  But I think I'll keep looking for  mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KYLE, a tough associate of Cobb's, hurries up to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cobb) He's getting out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle goes back up the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) C'mon, this'll interest you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb moves off after Kyle. Paden watches a moment  thoughtfully, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle is digging into a saddlebag on one of three saddled  horses at the gate of the stockade. Trooper guards flank entrance. Cobb comes up and stares at the gate. Paden rea the end of the sidewalk and leans against a post, watchin The heavy gate is opened and a jailkeep steps out into th sunlight; he looks back into the gloom. TYREE comes out,  wearing civilian clothes, shackled hand and foot. He's me The jailkeep unlocks Tyree's irons and steps back, a litt too quickly. Tyree nods at Cobb and a smile slits his fac Kyle comes up and hands Tyree his holster. Tyree buckles on and bends to tie it to his thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look who's here, Tyree. It's our old  riding buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyree looks up and straightens slowly at the sight of Pad No love lost. Cobb, standing between them, grins and then laughs. He takes the reins of his horse from Kyle and swi up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I invited Paden to join us, but he's  not having any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle and Tyree mount up. Tyree looks down at the longjohn Paden with a sneer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a knife) Where's the dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three head out of the village, passing Paden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Paden) You owe me thirteen bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb spurs his horse and the three gallop away in the dus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Thirteen... bad luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett and Paden come out of a restaurant. Paden is now b and fully dressed for the first time and he looks quite  different, better. The old gun he purchased is stuck in h belt. Three horses -- Emmett's, the pinto, Paden's bay -- are tied to the post in the street. Paden is fussing with his new, cheap hat. Emmett takes a  close look at Paden's bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see what you like, she's mighty  pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And bridle-wise, too. She's the only  thing I lost I really cared about. (he messes with his  hat, disgruntled) 'Cept for maybe my hat. It's a great  one. Got a pretty silver band on it.  My head spent three years training  it. (frowns at his new  hat) I surely do miss that hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett gives him an amused look; this sounds kind of fami Emmett unties his two horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta be going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going to Turley, was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Gotta meet a guy and head out for  Silverado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden takes the excess reins of the bay and begins idly  slapping them around the post, distracted. Emmett swings to his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's Turley like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he doesn't make  distinctions) It's a town...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got a saloon there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden takes a long time looking around the village's main street. It doesn't look promising. Emmett regards him wit growing bemusement. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you want to ride along with me  as far as Turley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden lights up slightly at the suggestion. He looks up a Emmett. This is how Paden makes his decisions these days. seems to be digesting it slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe... I'll ride along... as far  as Turley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett nods and turns his horses into the street. Paden m up and follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men, leading the pinto, make their way through de country to Turley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the corrals at the end of the main street of the sma town of Turley, a small WAGON TRAIN is loosely formed up, waiting. The settlers from the wagon train mill about. Se regard Emmett and Paden with unusual interest as they rid by on their way into town. One of the Settlers is a lovely young woman. She glances the two men, then returns her attention to her wagon. Bot Emmett and Paden notice her. She is HANNAH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall gallows is being constructed in the middle of an  intersection. Emmett and Paden look it over as they ride  past. Two workmen pause in their labors and look them ove

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the busy part of town. Amidst the street traffic pedestrians sits a wagon with three Settler men, who watc Emmett and Paden's arrival with enormous interest. As the two travelers hitch their horses in front of the saloon, oldest man, HOBART, approaches them with some agitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Baxter, Hawley, where the hell have  you been? You're late! And I'll tell  you, I don't like it. It's a bad  start, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett and Paden exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got my people sitting down  there... (indicates end of  street) ...swatting flies and raring to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it is a bad start, friend,  'cause my name isn't Baxter, and he  ain't Hawley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Emmett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Paden) And you're not Baxter, either?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not Hawley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, god-dammit! God-dammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobart turns and looks across to the other Settler men. H yells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't Baxter and Hawley! Where  the hell are Baxter and Hawley!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this commotion has attracted some attention and amuse from passersby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit your yelling, old man. We're  right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobart looks around to find two tough-looking men on hors back behind him -- BAXTER and HAWLEY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you calling an old man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter gets down from his horse and smiles, friendly for  him. Emmett and Paden watch with interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offers his hand) Calm down, Mr. Hobart. I'm Nord  Baxter. That there is my partner,  Tom Hawley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobart takes his hand grudgingly. He's glad they showed u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gruff) You're late. It's a bad start, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Yes, sir. We'll just have to get you  people to Silverado that much quicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett and Paden have continued to watch. Now Hawley look over at them suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Let's get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember my letter, don't you,  Mr. Hobart? Half now and half when  we get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remembering, impatient) I remember, I remember. C'mere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobart, Baxter, and Hawley move to the wagon, where the t other Settlers wait. The younger of the two, CONRAD, eyes the guides suspiciously. Hobart speaks to the third man, huge, bearded fellow called EB. Eb sits upon a strongbox the bed of the wagon, an awesome blunderbuss in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the box, Eb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eb stands, unlatches the strongbox, and opens it, reveali an impressive cache of coins and paper money. Hobart extr a pouch of coins and hands it to Baxter, who pockets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to count it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, friend. We trust you.  Now let's get this train on its way  to Silverado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett and Paden watch the other five men head in the  direction of the wagon train. Paden looks over at Emmett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the back of the big room is a registration desk for th hotel and stairs to the rooms. Emmett and Paden are eatin near a table of three Tough Men. Emmett is questioning a  WAITRESS, and his questions are making her nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He's about my size, energetic  young fella, wears two guns in a  fancy rig. He'd be a stranger here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving away quickly) I don't know him, I told you. I ain't  seen nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden, munching on a biscuit, has noticed something out i the street; he gets up and walks to the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT PADEN SEES. The wagon train is moving by. Paden's  attention is drawn to the seat of one of the wagons. Hann the lovely settler woman, is there; sitting beside her in husbandly manner is Conrad. Paden is interested enough in the pretty girl that he barely registers a new arrival at the saloon's hitching post. The newcomer takes his saddle bags and a Henry .44 rifle from his horse and comes up in the saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The newcomer is a lithe, strong, black man -- MAL. He has other weapon besides the rifle. Mal looks around the room and walks wearily to the registration desk, although ther is no one behind it. He RINGS a bell for service. At the sound of the bell several of the patrons look up a spot Mal for the first time. The three Tough Men are inst displeased at the sight of the black man. Paden, returnin to his meal, notes their attitude and glances over at Mal Mal leaves his saddlebags at the registration desk, but t the rifle as he walks across to the bar. The nervous Wait is working there. The sight of Mal only adds to her agita

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (friendly, tired) I haven't had a drink of whiskey or  slept in a bed for ten days. Give me  a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Waitress hesitates, uncertain. She places a shot glas and a bottle on the bar beyond an elaborate, brass, nude  statuette whose upraised arms hold dishes full of hard-bo eggs. Mal has leaned his rifle against the bar and must n move a few steps to stand before the whiskey. The three Tough Men exchange looks as Mal uncorks the bot and slowly, lovingly fills his shot glass. He puts the bo down and regards the glass for a long moment of pleasant  anticipation. Mal's hand has started for the glass when t saloon's PROPRIETOR appears from a back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Hey! What are you doing, buck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mal draws his hand back and straightens slightly. A diffe kind of weariness comes into his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not. Get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Proprietor shoots the Waitress a withering look; she  shrugs helplessly and hurries away. At the tables two of three Tough Men quietly rise and separate, moving toward two ends of the bar. Emmett and Paden watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flat) I haven't had a drink of whiskey or  slept in a bed for ten days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't getting them here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely) I'm real sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this, the First Man steps forward quickly, snatches Ma rifle, and slides it down the bar. Mal looks across the  distance at his only weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, to Emmett) Doesn't look quite fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching carefully) Which way do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Second Man lurches up to the bar and pins Mal's arms  behind him. The First Man moves quickly, cocking back his arm for a punch square in Mal's face. As the blow is  unleashed, Mal bends forward with terrific speed and forc pulling the Second Man onto his back. The Second Man's fa is suddenly where Mal's was an instant ago, and the First Man's punch lands hard on it. Mal slams the Second Man's  back against the edge of the bar; he falls to the floor. blocks a blow from the First Man and steps in with a flur of body blows. Back at the Tough Men's table, the Third Man pushes back chair as if to rise. Emmett has just picked up a chicken  leg; now he waves it ever so slightly at the Third Man: " out of it". The Man looks at Emmett and Paden, then settl back into his seat. Mal sends the First Man crashing down through a table wit final blow. He turns in time to see the Second Man, back his feet, grab Mal's whiskey bottle and break it against bar. Mal looks for a frustrated moment at the splashing  whiskey -- what a waste. The Second Man lunges with the s glass. Mal lifts the heavy statuette easily with one hand and uses its upraised arms to catch the Man's wrist and t the bottle painfully from his grasp. Mal's other hand hit the Man once in the throat, and he is down. The Proprietor rises from behind the bar, a sawed-off sho in his hand. Mal spins, swinging the statuette brutally  against the Proprietor's arm. The shotgun clatters to the floor as the Proprietor recoils in pain, crashing into a  shelf of glasses. The fight is over. Suddenly, standing in the doorway holding a leveled gun i an enormously tall figure -- SHERIFF LANGSTON. Dressed ra elegantly in suit and bowler, he dwarfs the man at his si DEPUTY KERN. He surveys the scene as the three injured me stir back to life. When he speaks, it is, surprisingly, w a British accent --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This nigger's breaking up my place,  Sheriff Langston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like that word much, Carter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't serve them here and you  know it. I asked him to leave and he  went crazy on us. He owes me money  for this damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a fact?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Fraid not, Sheriff. These other  fellas started the ruckus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Langston's attention focuses on Emmett and Paden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three strangers in this  room, traveller, and these gents you  are accusing aren't them. (to Mal, indicating  Emmett and Paden) Are these your friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head "no") I wanted a drink and a bed. I guess  I came to the wrong place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking in the mess) Came to the wrong town. I don't  tolerate this kind of thing. It's  hard on the peace, and it's hard on  the furniture. Now, knowing a bit  about Carter here, I'm going to let  you go without paying for the damages.  But go you will, and I mean now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a place in town that takes...  my kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You misunderstand. I want you out of  town. In fact, I want you all the  way out of my jurisdiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seething) That ain't right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I decide what's right in this  jurisdiction. Now move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mal glares at Langston and, finally, moves. He takes his  rifle from the bar, then walks over, picks up his saddleb and slings them over his shoulder. He is almost to the do when he stops, turns, and walks slowly back to the bar. T shot glass full of whiskey has miraculously survived the  fracas. Mal brings it to his lips and swallows with  satisfaction. He turns and goes out the front door. Langs motions to Deputy Kern to follow and witness Mal's depart Langston turns and looks at Emmett and Paden as he slowly uncocks his revolver and holsters it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's going to pay for all this,  Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't press your luck, Carter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Langston moves to Emmett and Paden's table and pulls up a chair. He lifts the last biscuit from a basket. He takes fastidious bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's talk about you chaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd rather stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see about that. I'm Sheriff  John Langston. As you may have  guessed, I am not from these parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring that) But the good citizens of Turley have  taken me in their embrace, and for  one simple reason. I maintain the  peace. So when strangers come to  town, I always ask them their  business. Have you come for the  hanging?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("no") I'm just meeting a guy here and moving  on. So far I haven't been able to  find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my town, when you're looking for  someone, you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'm looking for a young  fella, full of juice. About my size,  wears a fancy two-gun rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Langston takes a long time reacting to this information. he slides his chair back a foot, giving his gun hand a li more room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where that gentleman is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lean, young man is bouncing around his cell, playing ha sack, keeping a small, leather, bean bag from falling to floor by kicking it with his bare feet. This is JAKE. Langston opens the door to the cellblock and speaks over shoulder to Emmett and Paden, who have removed their guns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I want everyone to behave himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sight of Emmett, Jake's face lights up. And then h does an extraordinary thing: with one long stride he is a the cell and into the air; he hits the bars halfway up an clings like a monkey. Paden reacts as if he is one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett! Am I glad to see you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching him) Howdy, Jake. What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got me. This is a crazy town,  Emmett. I think we ought to get out  of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake lowers himself and darts about as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I did was kiss a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical) That's why they got you in jail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I kissed a girl and this guy  didn't like it and we had some words,  so I decided to get out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake looks at Emmett as though that should make it perfec clear. Emmett waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I did, I got out of there, I don't  want no trouble. You know me. (indeed, Emmett does) So I walked out on the street and  the fella tried to shoot me in the  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And you had to kill him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no! I winged him, and he  dropped his gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in here for winging a guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden watches, fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, not exactly. See then his  friend opened up on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What friend is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one with the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dead one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long moment of silence in the cellblock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, I'm going to ask you once --  was it self-defense?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment,  quieter now) Honest to God, Emmett, he would've  killed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jury saw it differently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting it all  together) So this is the guy you're going to  hang?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning. Ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) I was afraid of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett steps back and leans against the opposite wall, lo down at his boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett, can't you help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett looks up at the young man. He looks sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, you know the law. You know  what they did to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake remembers. It makes him gloomy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blind Pete always said you'd hang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake's eyes flick over Emmett, but his expression doesn't change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess tomorrow at dawn he'll be  proved right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten A.M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right... I thought they always did  it at dawn. (to Jake) So long, kid. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett walks out. Jake watches as the other two follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett and Paden walk along the sparsely populated sidewa They are quiet for a few moments. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shame about the kid. Seems a lively  sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (morosely) He is that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to see any man swing. Bad  luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad luck for me. Now I gotta bust  him out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden stops. Emmett has moved a couple more steps before notices and turns back to Paden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to deal me out on that.  I've had some experience with that  sort of thing, and I don't want any  more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not going to be easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It never is. But he's my brother. (Paden reacts) We're going to California together.  But first we're going to stop in  Silverado and see our sister. And I  can't show up there with a story  like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden nods. He is sympathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I guess this is where we part  ways. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No hard feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, I'll buy you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't got any money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you buy me a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross the street toward the crowded, noisy saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, a good smelly saloon is my  favorite place in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the busiest place in town, really packed. Emmett  heads for a spot at the bar, but Paden, who is taking in scene with relish, stops in his tracks, staring across th room. WHAT HE SEES. Through the moving jumble of bodies and the heavy smoke, Paden's hat with its silver band, floating a an unseen head at a poker table. Paden adjusts the old gun stuck in his belt and goes in t direction. At the table a heavy game is in progress. An UGLY COWBOY wearing Paden's hat. Paden plants himself across the tabl from the man. In seconds, Paden's posture brings things t halt. Quiet ripples out across the room. The Ugly Cowboy  looks up and recognizes Paden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wearing my hat. What else you  got that's mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking  about, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shifts a little in his chair. His right hand slides of the table. Bystanders back away. Emmett watches from the  bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope your hand isn't tickling my  bone-handled Colt. If you stand up  real slow and let me see, you might  live through this night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ugly Cowboy hesitates, his eyes darting. He pushes hi chair back slowly and begins to rise as if in compliance. But now a bone-handled Colt is in his hand, clearing his  holster. Paden is quicker. He snatches his gun from his b and fires. Paden's eyes, squinting through a cloud of gunsmoke, as w hear the Ugly Cowboy's body CRASH to the floor in his cha Paden's glance now darts down at an angle. WHAT HE SEES. His hat lands on the saloon floor, spins on on its brim, and settles into stillness like a tossed coi Silence in the saloon. Then, in a far corner, the BANGING chairs and a door SLAMMING. Paden's gun points that way, there is no one there. Only an overturned chair, and an e pair of boots -- Paden's. Paden picks up his hat and walks toward his boots. Emmett moves to the dead man, unbuckles the gunbelt, and pulls i free of the body. He picks up the bone-handled Colt and p it in the holster, then stops abruptly. We hear the stead advance of FOOTSTEPS across the saloon floor. Emmett's ey follow the off-screen presence. Paden, seated, is pulling on his newly-regained boots wit delighted air when a shadow surges up and engulfs him. He looks up. Sheriff Langston towers over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden is brusquely deposited in the cell next to a surpri Jake by Sheriff Langston and DEPUTY BLOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making a big mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Langston is not interested. He and Block go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I told 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deputy Block eyes Emmett, who loiters by the door as Lang settles himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I ought to throw you in jail  too. Then you could be with all your  friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't done anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you out of town before the  hanging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be long gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden forlornly regards a snoring drunk in another cell a Jake talks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you ain't coming with Emmett  and me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say I'm convinced you're  going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure we are. We're leaving at dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got no reason to run. It was a  fair fight and there were plenty of  witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bubbly) Yeah, that's what happened with me  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other guy drew first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same for him) Right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden looks a little discouraged, but is still unconvince

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett sits up on the new gallows in the deserted  intersection, his legs dangling through the dropped trap  door. Now he begins idly collecting wood shavings into a  little pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden steps close to the bars that separate the cells and looks up at Jake, who is dangling at arm's length from on of the overhead bars in his cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Your brother seems pretty good, but  it isn't going to be easy getting in  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake drops down to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't coming in, we're going out. (motions) Gimme your belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden, trying to follow this, unbuckles his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't he tell you about Blind Pete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him the belt) We didn't get that far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blind Pete taught me a great trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake grasps Paden's belt by the buckle and snaps it at Pa with a CRACK, like a lion tamer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deputy Block cheats at solitaire while Langston dozes at desk. Now we hear FOOTSTEPS and BANGING outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff! Sheriff! Open up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Block unlocks the door as Langston comes groggily to life STABLE BOY bounces at the door, pointing off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Langston, come quick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disappears. Langston goes out, calling back to Block -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock this door and don't let anybody  in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Langston hurries up the street after the Stable Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deputy Block bolts the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Hey! What are you doing, you crazy  kid? Don't do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Block draws his six-gun and edges suspiciously toward the door to the cellblock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus! Somebody stop him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Block turns the doorknob and pushes the door open with hi foot, gun ready. He moves into the cellblock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Block moves cautiously to where he can see the cells. A  strange look crosses his face. Jake is hanging by the neck from the overhead bars, two b forming the noose, his head at a disgusting angle from hi body. One foot gives a final twitch and he is still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut him down! For God's sake, cut  him down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Block is confused, uncertain. He doesn't want to go in th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up! You might be able to save  him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? So we can hang him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden, sincerely desperate now, looks up at Jake, whose f is turning blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to be sick... when  I see what Langston does to you when  he gets here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Block lets it sink in, then takes some keys from his belt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Paden) You get way back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden moves back quickly, motioning for Block to hurry. B holsters his six-gun, opens Jake's cell door, and goes in He gets up on the cot, pulling a knife from a sheath. He  strains up against Jake's body, stretching to cut the bel Suddenly Jake can stand it no longer: he sputters to life his long-held breath blasting in Block's face. Block,  startled, stumbles backwards off the cot, raising the kni threateningly. Jake grabs the overhead bars, swings up, a kicks Block in the chest. The deputy careens across the c and hits the bars. He throws the knife outside the cell a draws his gun, ready to shoot Jake. As Block's finger pulls the trigger, Paden's thumb intrud between the hammer and the firing pin. Paden has reached  through the bars behind Block to grasp the gun with his r hand. Now with his left he grabs a handful of Block's hai and slams the deputy's head hard back against the bars. A Block slides unconscious to the floor, Paden keeps the gu wincingly uncocking it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to be real quiet here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake has unhooked himself and is freeing his makeshift no He rubs his reddened neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a hoarse whisper) Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Langston huffs to a stop next to the Stable Boy, his  countenance a picture of outraged befuddlement. He, the S Boy, and just one other surprised citizen are the only  witnesses: the gallows is aflame, burning like a pyre. Langston considers this phenomenon, a suspicion slowly gr in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden and Jake come out warily. The street is deserted. P straps his holster on; he's glad to have it back at last. Not as glad, however, as Jake, who seems to have a nearly religious relationship with his rig, an elaborately toole double gunbelt with two pearl-handled Colts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the longest I ever did it.  'Bout bust a gut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finger to lips:  "quiet") What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men move carefully off the porch and into the str A wood stair goes up the outside of the jail to a door. N high behind Jake, Deputy Kern comes out, nightshirt flapp cocking the carbine in his hands. He has thumped down fiv steps before he focuses on Jake and Paden. He starts to r the carbine. Both men see the deputy, but Jake's reaction is so fast t Paden need only watch. Jake spins and, before he has stop both his Colts are erupting in his hands. The carbine fli out of Kern's grasp and clatters down the steps. Jake  continues to fire -- the stair at Kern's foot splinters a he steps backwards and up. Jake continues to splinter the steps at Kern's feet, until he has made the deputy exactl retrace his steps and retreat back through the door. The  firing stops. Paden gives Jake an odd look. Paden may have seen someone this fast and good before, but he can't remember it. He p his finger to his lips -- "shhh".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reloading fast) He'll be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bullet WHIZZES between the two men as we hear shots fro the far end of the street. Langston is coming toward them firing. They move back to the cover of the jail porch. ALLEY ACROSS THE STREET. Emmett roars into view, riding h horse and leading two others: Paden's bay and the pinto. A window above the jail breaks open and Kern starts firin at Emmett. DOWN THE STREET. Langston, behind a wagon, uses a British two-handed grip to fire off a few rounds. Emmett brings the horses over, and Paden swings quickly u Jake focuses his attention, unleashing a fusillade as Emm leads the pinto along the front of the jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWN THE STREET. Langston lifts his head from behind the bullet-pocked wagon. He's impressed. Jake runs along the porch, hits the top of the hitching p on the fly, and takes off, landing lightly in the saddle the pinto. The three men gallop out of town in a cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men ride hell-for-leather away from town. At th first bend they leave the road and head off cross-country their horses straining up craggy hillsides and sliding do dusty slopes. There is some good riding going on here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUTTING the three men and the Posse Langston has rai as the Posse closes ground over choppy terrain. Now the t fugitives come through some trees along the bank of a str and splash across to the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men come thundering along a dusty trail to the  place where it splits. The high road disappears up the si of a ridge; the low road is really the bed of an arroyo. three men exchange looks. Paden plunges into the arroyo.  Emmett shrugs to Jake, and the brothers follow Paden. INTERCUTTING. The Posse splashes across the stream. The t fugitives twist their way through the crooked arroyo. AT THE SPLIT IN THE TRAIL. Langston pulls his group to a  halt. He looks at the tracks leading into the arroyo, and smile splits his face. He leads the Posse up the high roa fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE ARROYO. Paden and Emmett pull up, looking back at  Jake, who has stopped at the last bend in the gully, watc their rear. Now he rides up to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we lost 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nobody coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake shakes his head "no". Paden and Emmett exchange long looks. Paden looks to the ground above them, even more  worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They spur their horses out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three riders break out of the arroyo and exchange loo of glee on seeing the clear flatlands ahead. SHOTS ring o They look over their shoulders to see Langston's Posse,  practically on top of them, pouring over the lip of a ris and firing at will. The three men whip their horses and head flat out across open space toward a cluster of boulders three hundred yar away. They are vulnerable and exposed as shots PING aroun them. They are not going to make it. WITH THE POSSE. Deputy Block jumps from his horse onto th top of a boulder and lies prone, bracing his Winchester f an accurate shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Let's see you fake this one, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is about to fire when suddenly the rocky surface in fr of his face explodes. He is so startled, he falls off the boulder. Another Posse member is coming between two tall rocks whe bullet hits near his head and ricochets into the rock on other side. His horse rears up, and the horse coming up b him collides with it. Langston and Deputy Kern have just started across the fla but pull up next to a cactus at this new firing. An arm o the cactus is immediately severed by a .44 slug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that them shooting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) No. It's coming from those rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT HE SEES. Paden, Emmett, and Jake are now halfway to cover of the distant rocks. Another shot CRACKS, and a pu of smoke appears from ahead of them in the boulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. He ain't hitting anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You idiot, he's hit everything he's  aimed at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But they won't be out of our  jurisdiction till they pass Flat  Top!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paden, Emmett, and Jake disappear among the boulders,  Langston rises high in his stirrups to catch a final glim His bowler is blown off his head. He lowers himself back his saddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today my jurisdiction ends here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his horse back. The others do likewise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder,  to Kern) Pick up my hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett and Paden rein in their frothing horses in the nat bowl of rocks near a tied horse and the remains of a camp Jake has stopped short of them and taken his horse back t peer out toward the Posse. Grinning, he comes back to the others. The three riders bring their horses around and fo on a spot above them. On the top of the highest boulder, Mal leaves a comfortab prone shooting position and eases himself down to a lower rock. A bandolier of .44 bullets dangles from one hand. H rests his Henry rifle at an angle across one shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the others) This a friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a guy who got run out of town...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...just like us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awesome rock spire soars into the perfect blue sky abo the orange desert. The sight is spectacular. The slow sur of MUSIC exhilarating. It is the perfect setting in which see the four horsemen who now appear on a ridge. Here the come -- Riding together, side by side, for the first time -- Emme Paden, Jake, and Mal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The travellers crest a hill above a wide desert plain and pull up at the surprising sight below -- there in the  distance, stopped dead in a disorderly line, is the wagon train we saw leave Turley. The horsemen exchange puzzled  looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Settlers are clustered near a wagon as the four horse ride down on them. There is a tense silence as they dismo and approach the group. Hobart, the leader, steps forward meet them. After a long perusal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) It's okay, Zeke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the cover of a nearby wagon, Zeke appears, lowering shotgun that had been trained on the newcomers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobart, what are you people doing  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where Baxter and Hawley brung  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they're wrong. This territory  is full of bad characters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they were two of them. Look --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures and the Settlers part to reveal the wagon whi held the money box in Turley. The money box is gone, but still form of its giant guardian, Eb, lies in the bed of wagon, dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter and Hawley killed poor Eb  here and stole our money box. (gestures) They went north and we're going after  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The newcomers now see that a few of the Settler men and b are preparing to ride in pursuit. Mal and Paden exchange  looks, not terribly impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget the money. You've got to get  these people out of here. This is no  place to be sitting with women and  kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your next water ain't for three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got no life in Silverado without  that money. Everybody put in, that's  our whole stake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden looks around. His gaze falls on Hannah, somber now, but still lovely. Conrad, her husband, stands beside her. Mal has been watching a little girl cling to the leg of o of the Settler men who is going out on the chase. Now the black man quietly mounts his horse, and speaks to an olde solid-looking man, MR. PARKER, standing by his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have they been gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett and Paden watch Mal with interest. Jake is excited this development. He jumps up on his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go with you, Mal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden isn't so quick to commit, but then he notices Hanna gazing up at Mal and Jake with radiant admiration. He dig that and moves toward his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steals a look at Hannah as he mounts up. Emmett has wa all this with growing resignation. Now he speaks crisply, all business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, you know the way out of here.  I want you to get this train moving  toward Silverado, and fast. I'll go  with these guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake is disappointed, but nods agreement. Emmett turns to Hobart and the Settler posse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You men stay with your wagons and  your families. Get rolling and keep  your eyes peeled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett moves toward his horse, as Conrad, rifle in hand,  steps forward belligerently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! If you do get the  money, how do we know you'll come  back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flashes him a look) If we don't, you can keep my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Emmett) I'm trusting you, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hobart) You trusted Baxter. I'm not letting  these men out of my sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conrad moves toward his horse, Paden looks at Hannah, standing all alone. Paden thinks he acted too quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Hannah) If I'd brought a pretty lady like  that into a place like this, I'd  stay close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden reacts to Emmett's interest in Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's none of your business, mister.  Let's get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, to Emmett) I think you got a point, Emmett.  Maybe I better stay here with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett smiles and snaps his reins, moving out with Mal.  Reluctantly, Paden follows, twisting around for a last gl of Hannah. WHAT HE SEES. Hannah moves toward Conrad's horse, as if t touch her husband. But Conrad, his face set in suspicion, barely nods farewell as he sweeps by her. She looks after him desolately. Mal, Paden, Emmett, and Conrad ride off to the north, as  Jake begins yelling orders to the Settlers to get things  moving. What he lacks in expertise, he makes up for in  enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four men track the killers across the rugged terrain. Sometimes, Emmett gets down from his horse to examine the tracks. On a flat, rocky expanse, the chase party is temporarily  stalled. Emmett and Paden confer, balked. Mal, peering ah spots something and points it out to the two expert track a steaming horse patty. They head off in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four men crawl to the lip of the canyon and get a cle view of the activity below; the box canyon has been turne into a hideout for the Dawson Gang, a band of border raid There are about twenty-five outlaws moving about among th tents, caves, and wagons of the encampment. Their horses penned in a natural alcove in the rock off the main floor the canyon. The strongbox from the wagon train sits on the tailgate o wagon. Next to it is a large keg of whiskey from which th outlaws are drawing generous portions. Baxter and Hawley  have brought the loot proudly back to their cohorts, and celebration is centered around this wagon. On the rim the pursuers exchange looks in reaction to thi new situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Emmett) You know, hanging around with you is  no picnic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody got any ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the outlaws spills some whiskey onto the money in strongbox. DAWSON, the leader of the gang, angrily slams strongbox closed and kicks the offending outlaw. Suddenly there are cries of warning from the Sentinel at the entra to the box canyon. HOOFBEATS echo into the canyon from th direction. The outlaws react en masse with a frightening  display of armed readiness. WHERE THE TRAIL ENTERS THE CANYON. From the shadows emerg two galloping horses: on the first is Emmett, who holds t reins of the second, across whose saddle is draped the  seemingly lifeless body of Paden. The Sentinel watches th pass under the point of his carbine. AT THE WAGON. Emmett dismounts quickly and ties both hors to a wheel. Dawson decides not to shoot this guy yet. He  watches as Emmett runs back across the canyon to the cove of some crates and crouches down behind them, looking up the rim above the entrance. The outlaws, guns pointed, st around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dawson) Should I kill him, Mr. Dawson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching Emmett) In a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett, still cowering, looks over his shoulder at Dawson He speaks now, and throughout, very fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't do that. You're going to  need every gun when that posse gets  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Posse? What the hell you talking  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My partner and me robbed the bank in  Turley and headed out with a posse  on our tails. My partner there caught  one a ways back, and I think he kicked  off while I was looking for this  damn canyon. You're Dawson, ain't  you? I'm Tex LaRue. (offers his hand for  only a second) Used to ride with Ry Morris. You  know him. Well, Andy Sims told me  there was a hideout here, so I headed  for it. Hope you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden, lying over the saddle, his face shielded by his ha winces at this story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought a posse to my best hideout  and you want to know if I mind.  Mister, I don't know any of those  names and you're about to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! If you don't believe  me, ask them... (indicates Baxter and  Hawley) ...they saw me and my pal in Turley  before we did the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter and Hawley peer at Emmett and nod to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw 'em there, all right, but I  don't know about any bank job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you took the bank in Turley,  where's the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett crouches lower, looking nervously at the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd get down if I were you. They may  be up there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just as he suspected) No money, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money's in my saddlebags over  there, but I ain't stepping out to  get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outlaws, all of whom are standing in the open, think  he's crazy. Dawson motions Hawley toward Emmett's horse.  Hawley is almost there when gunfire erupts from the rocks above and Hawley goes down dead. Now all the outlaws hit dirt, some firing wildly. Paden unobtrusively frees his r Dawson comes down beside Emmett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conrad and Mal fire into the canyon, then move to new  positions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABOVE THE ENTRANCE to the box canyon the Sentinel disappe into the rocks, moving upward. AT THE CRATES. Down the line from Emmett, an outlaw gets  hit. The outlaws can't see anything to shoot at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agitated) If we charge them, they won't have a  chance. But we gotta get to the  horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, the horses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett jumps up. He yells to the other outlaws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cover me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs in a mad zig-zag toward the gate of the horses' p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mal, firing rapidly, follows Emmett's route with precisio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mal's shots kick up dust inches from Emmett's flying feet Once Emmett throws a glance upwards; Mal's cutting it pre close. Baxter slides in next to Dawson, who is thinking h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Emmett) Brave man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think there's only a couple of  guys up there and this asshole's one  of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AT THE WAGON. An outlaw is cowering beneath the wagon, bu doesn't notice as Paden reaches out and secures the latch the money box. AT THE HORSE PEN. Emmett throws open the make-shift gate runs in among the horses, yelling and waving his arms. Th horses begin to run out of the pen. AT THE CRATES. Dawson jumps up and orders his men forward line of outlaws rushes toward the pen, all the while firi up at the rim. Paden appears at a gallop from behind, pul Emmett's horse beside him. A rope stretches from his  saddlehorn to the strongbox bouncing along in the dirt. Paden comes through the line of outlaws firing and heads the pen. A few of the outlaws make the mistake of closing the gap and aiming at Paden's back. The bouncing strongbo knocks them head over heels. Emmett leaps from a rock onto his passing horse, firing b him. He and Paden go down the trail in the midst of the  outlaws' horses. The strongbox careens after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mal and Conrad, mounted; are waiting as Emmett and Paden  ride out of the mouth of the canyon. Beyond them, the out horses scatter toward the horizon. Paden jumps off his ho and picks up the strongbox. IN THE ROCKS ABOVE THEM the Sentinel from the outlaw camp positions himself to fire at the men below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mal) That was some idea of yours. Next  time you go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden is tying the strongbox to his saddlehorn when there the loud CLICK of Conrad's rifle being cocked. He nervous points it at the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it. Put that box on my horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, you got a lot to learn about  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHOT rings out. Conrad takes it in the chest and flies his horse. Now an amazing sight -- Emmett, Paden, and Mal all turn and fire at once. The Sentinel is really dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Below in the distance the wagon train moves across the de dwarfed by giant rock walls. Now, coming right PAST CAMER at a gallop ride Emmett, Paden, Mal, and Conrad's horse w his body slung over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah sits alone on the high seat of her wagon. She is  unaware that behind her the four horses approach. And tha her husband is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mal, Emmett, and Jake lounge about a campfire within the  quiet circle of wagons. Emmett is whittling a whistle pip out of a stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the war my family worked a  little piece of land near Savannah  for a while. But the way it was down  there then... well, they made it  hard every way they could. Finally  my daddy figured the promised land  was out this direction. By that time  I was so sick of farming, I didn't  want to touch another hoe ever. I  wouldn't come with 'em. My daddy  took it pretty hard. Him, my ma, and  my little sister headed out without  me. They've got a little place south  of Silverado. I guess they've done  okay. Good enough anyway so that  when my ma wrote me last time, she  said they needed my help to work the  place. That was almost nine months  ago she wrote. Letter took a while  to find me, but when it did, it was  just the right time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicago. Working in the slaughter- houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicago! You been to Chicago? Was it  wonderful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remembering) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paden walks into the light of the fire and pours himself cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caught, vamps) Oh, I was just checking the, ah... (gestures vaguely  over his shoulder) ...you know, lookin' in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He concentrates on his coffee and moves away from the lig Mal, Emmett, and Jake exchange amused, knowing looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, Paden, her old man ain't even  cold yet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mal and Emmett laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS as the wagon train rolls westward. Paden is driving Hannah's wagon; she sits beside him on t seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He acted bravely out there, Hannah.  Just bad luck his getting hit. Could  have been any one of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe in luck. I know what  Conrad was like. Don't tell me what  you think I want to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never will again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got married just before this trip,  so we could come out here and try  the land. It's hard to find a man  willing to take on a life like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses and takes the reins from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love isn't the only important thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmett rides up on Hannah's side and keeps pace beside th smiling at the sight of the couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doing, m'am? Getting enough  help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah, caught between the two men, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you thought at all about your  plans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some. I've been talking to the  Parkers. One thing I know I'm not  doing -- I'm not going back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wagon train splashes noisily across the river, driver yelling loudly to urge on their teams. Emmett, Paden, Mal and Jake, on horseback, direct the crossing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wagon train is moving through pretty, rolling country Mal rides up to join Emmett and Paden on point ahead of t train. In his hand is a yellowed letter. He points off to the south where a dramatic half-dome of rock towers above the hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it, gents. My ma told me to  head south past that rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, Mal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we'll see you sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't think so) Yeah... maybe. So long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rides away, and he doesn't look back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buckboard with a man and a young girl in it is stopped the fork, its two occupants standing up and waving excite As the wagon train pulls to a halt, Hobart climbs down fr the lead wagon and is embraced by the homesteader from th buckboard, BRADLEY. Bradley points off along the right fork of the road as he speaks to Hobart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right down this road aways.  I'll ride in with you myself. (to the girl in the  buckboard) Carol, go spread the word our people  are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl, CAROL, whips the buckboard into motion and  disappears down the road. Bradley is looking down the lin of wagons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought there'd be more of you.  But I thank the Lord for each and  every one. We'll have a solid strip  of bottomland under the plow when  you people stake your claims. (a grim look at Hobart) And we're going to need every hand  to hold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AT HANNAH'S WAGON. Emmett has brought his horse up to fac Hannah and, on horseback beside her wagon, Paden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope to see you again, m'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods demurely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll ride along with the  lady here. Just take a look at this  farmland before I come into Silverado.  See what makes a trip this hard worth  taking. (catches Emmett's  amused look) I'll see you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AT THE LEAD WAGON. Hobart has what might be tears in his  eyes as he picks up the reins and looks at the countrysid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I've arrived in Canaan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we got here, we thought it was  Eden. And it's pretty close -- right  down to the serpents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wagon train moves out along the right fork of the roa as Emmett and Jake, waving goodbye, ride straight ahead t town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silverado is a sprawling, active, handsome frontier town, cattle center and supply station for the burgeoning silve mines to the west. Emmett and Jake ride into town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mal comes around the shoulder of a hill and reins to a ha He takes the yellowed letter from his pocket and checks a detail. He smiles at the stand of cottonwoods that marks route. After all these years, he's excited to be approach some kind of home. He hurries on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
